questions.text: In which segment of the tubular system is the fluid hyperosmotic?

options.text: Bowman capsule
end of thick segment of the loop of Henle
distal tubule
thin segment of the loop of Henle (tip of the loop)
proximal tubule

questions.text: What is the most important mechanism of Cl- reabsorption in the proximal tubule?

options.text: anion exchange (Cl- - HCO3- antiport)
Na-K-2Cl cotransport
cotransport with H+ ions
paracellular reabsorption driven by the voltage gradient after the primary reabsorption of Na+

questions.text: Which of the following transport is important for establishing the osmotic gradient in the renal medulla?

options.text: reabsorption of Na+ in the proximal tubule
Na-K-2Cl cotransport in the thick segment of the loop of Henle
Na+-reabsorption in the cortical collecting duct
vasopressin-stimulated reabsorption of water in the collecting duct
aldosterone-stimulated reabsorption of Na+ in the collecting duct

questions.text: The renal recirculation of urea

options.text: involves urea reabsorption by the intercalated cells
is a mechanism contributing to the creation the osmotic gradient in the medulla
promotes the excretion of dilute urine
is inhibited by vasopressin
is stimulated by vasopressin
requires UT-1 transporters in the thin segment of the loop of Henle

questions.text: What is the most important mechanism of Cl- reabsorption in the proximal tubule?

options.text: anion exchange (Cl- - HCO3- antiport)
H+-Cl- antiporter (primary active pump)
paracellular reabsorption driven by the voltage gradient after the primary reabsorption of Na+
cotransport with H+ ions
Na-K-2Cl cotransport

questions.text: The Na-K-2Cl cotransporter in the kidney

options.text: resides in the luminal membrane of the proximal convoluted tubulus
is a transporter directly using ATP (ATPase)
is inhibited by thiazides
is a secondary active transport for the K+ and the Cl-
mediates aldosterone-stimulated Na+-reabsorption
resides in the luminal membrane of the thick segment of the loop of Henle

questions.text: The absorptive capabilities of the different tubular segments vary as follows (S)

options.text: about 65% of all reabsorption that occurs in the tubular system takes part in the loop of Henle
sodium is transported downhill along the concentration gradient from the proximal tubules into the interstitial fluid
the thick segment of the loop of Henle shows a marked transport of sodium but it is almost impermeable to urea
the active sodium transport in the distal tubules and collecting duct epithelium requires ADH

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is involved in the tubular Na+ reabsorption? (S)

options.text: active discharge of Na+ from the epithelial cells into the interstitial space
transport of Na+ against a concentration gradient from the tubular lumen into the epithelial cells
a negative charge of the intratubular fluid
carrier proteins for Na+ in the basal membrane of the epithelial cells
a concentration gradient for Na+ from the glomerular filtrate towards the interstitial fluid
intratubular hydrostatic pressure is higher than the interstitial hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: In Na-dependent secondary active transport, metabolic energy is directly used to transport (S)

options.text: glucose across the brush border membrane
glucose across the basolateral membrane
Na+ across the brush border membrane
Na+ across the basolateral membrane
none of the above is correct

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT correct? In the kidney (S)

options.text: the discharge of Na+ from the tubular epithelial cells into the interstitial space is the active component of the tubular Na+ transport
there is a concentration gradient for Na+ from the lumen of the tubule into the epithelial cell
Na+ uptake from the tubular lumen into the epithelial cell occurs against an electrochemical gradient
Na+ transport from the lumen into the epithelial cell uses carrier proteins

questions.text: The kidney "handles" K+ by (S)

options.text: filtration only
filtration and reabsorption only
filtration and secretion only
filtration, secretion, and reabsorption
none of the above is correct

questions.text: ADH is a peptide hormone (M)

options.text: produced in the hypothalamus
produced in the posterior pituitary
produced in the anterior pituitary
produced in the adrenal cortex
produced in the neurohypophysis
produced in the juxtaglomerular apparatus

questions.text: ADH exerts its action on the kidney by increasing (S)

options.text: free-water clearance
renal medullary blood flow
free-water reabsorption
proximal tubular reabsorption of sodium
proximal tubular reabsorption of water

questions.text: Aldosterone deficiency (Addison's disease) is characterized by (S)

options.text: increased hematocrit
increased blood pressure
acidosis
hypokalemia
hyperglycemia
none of the above is correct

questions.text: The effect of ADH is

options.text: increase the water permeability of the proximal tubules
increase the permeability of the peritubular capillaries
increase the capillary permeability in the glomerulus
regulate the filtration slits
increase the water permeability of the collecting tubules

questions.text: Na+ can be transported across the luminal membrane of renal tubular cells by

options.text: diffusion through Na+ channels
co-transport with organic solutes
counter transport for H+
the Na-K ATPase

questions.text: Which of the following transports are hormone-regulated?

options.text: Na+ reabsorption in the thick ascending segment - vasopressin
K+ secretion in the collecting duct - aldosterone
Na+ reabsorption in the proximal tubule - aldosterone
Na+ reabsorption in the collecting duct - ANH
Ca2+ reabsorption in the distal tubule - PTH
K+ reabsorption in the distal tubule - aldosterone

questions.text: In the loop of Henle

options.text: water is reabsorbed from the descending limb
little or no water is reabsorbed from the ascending limb
active solute reabsorption occurs in the ascending limb
active solute reabsorption occurs in the descending limb mainly

questions.text: Which segment of the tubular system is characterized by the highest osmotic concentration in the human kidney?

options.text: ascending thick segment of the loop of Henle
proximal convoluted tubule
the total length of the distal convoluted tubule
the beginning of the distal convoluted tubule
end of the collecting tubule

questions.text: A patient is treated with a drug that causes the formation of a large volume of urine with an osmolarity of 100 mOsm/l. The actions of this drug include:

options.text: inhibition of ADH secretion
inhibition of the tubular V2 receptors
inhibition of Na-K-2Cl cotransport by the thick segment of the ascending limb of the loop of Henle
inhibition of renin secretion
increased water permeability of the distal tubule and collecting duct

questions.text: A major mechanism of Na+-reabsorption in the proximal tubulus is as follows

options.text: exchange for K+ (Na+ - K+ - 2Cl-)
exchange for K+
exchange for H+ resulting in net Na+ and HCO3- absorption
exchange for Ca2+

questions.text: Which segment of the tubular system is characterized by the highest osmotic concentration in the concentrating kidney?

options.text: ascending thick segment of the loop of Henle
proximal convoluted tubule
the total length of the distal convoluted tubule
the beginning of the distal convoluted tubule
end of the collecting tubule

questions.text: Which transport is modulated by ANH in the kidney? ANH inhibits

options.text: amiloride-sensitive Na channels in the collecting duct
Na-K exchange in the proximal tubule
vasopressin-stimulated water reabsorption in the collecting duct
Na-K-2Cl cotransporter in the thick segment

questions.text: A patient is treated with a diuretic for the formation of a large volume of urine with an osmolarity of 100 mOsm/l. The actions of this drug include:

options.text: inhibition of ADH secretion
inhibition of the tubular V2 receptors
decreased active Cl- reabsorption by the thick segment of the ascending limb of the loop of Henle
inhibition of renin secretion
increased water permeability of the distal tubule and collecting duct

questions.text: A major mechanism of Na+-reabsorption in the proximal tubulus is as follows

options.text: cotransport with Cl- and K+ (Na+ - K+ - 2Cl-)
exchange for K+
exchange for H+ resulting in net Na+ and HCO3- absorption
exchange for Ca2+

questions.text: Which cells in the kidney express vacuolar H+-pump?

options.text: epithelial cells of the proximal tubule
principals cells in the collecting duct
intercalated cells in the collecting duct
epithelial cells of the distal tubule
epithelial cells of the thick segment of the loop of Henle

questions.text: A major mechanism of Na+-reabsorption in the proximal tubulus is as follows

options.text: exchange for Ca2+
exchange for H+ resulting in net Na+ and HCO3- absorption
cotransport of Cl- and K+ (Na+-K+-2Cl-)
exchange for K+

questions.text: What is the direct cellular action of aldosterone in the collecting duct?

options.text: opening of luminal Na+-channels
increasing the number of the luminal Na+ channels
activation of their cytoplasm
blocking of ANH receptors
opening of the luminal K+ channels

questions.text: The function of the thick segment of the loop of Henle is best described by

options.text: reabsorption of sodium accompanied by water
reabsorption of NaCl and impermeability to water and urea
reabsorption of urea resulting in an increased osmolarity of the medullary interstitium
water reabsorption which reduces the volume of urine
secretion of potassium
exchange of various substances
sodium transport regulated by aldosterone
intense H+ secretion

questions.text: Which of the following transports are hormone-regulated?

options.text: Na+ reabsorption in the proximal tubule - aldosterone
K+ reabsorption in the distal tubule - aldosterone
K+ secretion in the collecting duct - aldosterone
K+ reabsorption in the thick ascending segment - vasopressin
Na+ reabsorption in the collecting duct - aldosterone
Ca2+-reabsorption in the distal tubule - PTH

questions.text: Diabetes insipidus:

options.text: daily urine production may exceed 14-15 liters
also known as diabetes mellitus
usually caused by elevated blood AVP (ADH) levels
may cause hyperhydration (water intoxication)
usually presents with glycosuria

questions.text: What is the source of ammonium ions secreted by the renal tubuli?

options.text: amine groups of glutamine
side chain amine groups of basic amino acids (arginine, lysine)
amino groups from urea reabsorbed in the tubuli
ammonium ions circulating in the blood plasma

questions.text: Which statement is true concerning Ca reabsorption in the kidney?

options.text: Parathyroid hormone enhances Ca reabsorption in the distal tubule
There is an active Ca reabsorption in the proximal tubule
Parathyroid hormone enhances Ca reabsorption in the collecting ducts
Parathyroid hormone enhances Ca reabsorption in the Loop of Henle
Parathyroid hormone enhances Ca reabsorption in the proximal tubule
There is an active Ca reabsorption in the distal tubule

questions.text: Which tubular segment is the action site of furosemide type diuretics inhibiting the Na+K+2Cl- transporter?

options.text: collecting duct
proximal convoluted tubule
thick ascending segment of the loop of Henle
distal convoluted tubule

questions.text: The physiological importance of the juxtamedullary (long-loop) nephrons is as follows

options.text: they are shorter than the cortical nephrons in the kidney: they do not participate in the production of urine
they produce more concentrated glomerular filtrate than the rest of the nephrons
they are the major source of renin
they determine the capacity of the kidney to concentrate the urine

questions.text: Where is the largest fraction of filtered K+ reabsorbed in the kidney?

options.text: in the thick segment of the loop of Henle
in the collecting duct
in the proximal tubule
in the distal tubule

questions.text: Which tubular segment is the action site of the thiazide type diuretics?

options.text: distal tubule
proximal tubule
thick segment of the loop of Henle
collecting duct

questions.text: What is characteristic of the thick segment of the loop of Henle?

options.text: the Na reabsorption is stimulated by aldosterone
this is where the largest fraction of filtered Na is reabsorbed
the tubular fluid becomes hypoosmotic
large amount of water flows into the interstitium
